body: IN the sometimes flamboyant world of property development, Joshua L. Muss has established a reputation as an unobtrusive builder. ''He just quietly goes ahead and figures out how to develop a project,'' said Steven Spinola, the president of the Real Estate Board of New York, who has known Mr. Muss for about 25 years. Recently, at a site in
title: SQUARE FEET: INTERVIEW -- WITH JOSHUA L. MUSS; Away From the Limelight, A Builder Makes His Mark

body: ON Monday, Jan. 18, 1909, New Yorkers woke to a city transformed. A weekend storm of snow and sleet had left everything -- the biggest trees and the smallest bushes, the trolley wires and street lamps -- coated and gleaming with ice, as if made of glass. It was, wrote a reporter for The Brooklyn Daily Eagle, ''as if the fairy queen of childhood
title: Long-Ago Snow

title: Women Unafraid Of Condo Commitment

title: Challenging a Tax Break For Housing Developers

That is the Brooklyn that Clinton Irving Jones set out to preserve in photographs. From 1905 to 1911, he

body: For the last 35 years, New York has given housing developers an enormous tax break, worth $400 million in just the last fiscal year. The incentive made sense when it was conceived, during the tenure of Mayor John Lindsay, when the city was in fiscal crisis and needed to pull out all the stops to encourage residential building. More recently,
title: Ending a Housing Giveaway

title: THEATER REVIEW; A Guided Tour of Hell, With an Appearance by Satan

body: The Bloomberg administration plans to recommend that the city's most popular tax break for housing developers be overhauled as a way of creating a more powerful incentive to build lower-cost housing. The announcement, scheduled for today, would be the first major change in the program, known as 421-a, in the 35 years since it was conceived. Under
title: CITY ACTS TO ADD LOW-COST HOMES

body: THE Brooklyn Navy Yard is in the early stages of a more than $100 million renovation, one its overseers hope will give a further boost to the long-neglected former shipbuilding site, which has bounced back in recent years and now has more than 200 tenants. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN WATERFRONT; A Shipyard's Rebirth, Guided by the Past

body: A 7-year-old Coney Island girl and her father were found shot to death yesterday in the man's apartment after he telephoned the child's mother and threatened to kill the girl, the police said. Details about the shootings, including the motive, remained unclear last night, hours after the police said they received a call from the distraught mother
title: Girl and Father Found Dead After Mother Reports Threat

body: It is probably safe to say that few New Yorkers were aware on Wednesday that they were supposed to be aware. That is no doubt because many of us, to borrow a line made famous in a different context, never miss an opportunity to miss an opportunity. Wednesday happened to be National School Backpack Awareness Day. Don't feel bad if you did not know.
title: NYC; Heavy Books, Heavy Packs, Aching Backs

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Sept. 17-23; DANCE

title: Disputed Plan In Brooklyn

body: Sweat darkened the brim of Nicholas Evans-Cato's straw hat last week as he brushed oil paint onto a six-foot-wide canvas, all the while perched on the tar-paper roof of an old factory building in Dumbo, Brooklyn. It was scorching hot up there, but Mr. Evans-Cato had no time to waste. In front of him was a half-finished painting of the Brooklyn
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DUMBO; Now You Paint 'Em, Now You Don't

title: URBAN TACTICS; Tulips and Two-By-Fours

title: FOOD STUFF; To Improve on Chocolate, Tuck in Some Ice Cream

body: ON the site of what was once a beachfront hotel called Curly's and then, for decades, a vacant lot in the neighborhood of Rockaway Park, there is now the Ocean Grande, an eight-story luxury condominium building set to open to residents in a few weeks. The building, at the corner of Beach 117th Street and the Rockaway Boardwalk, is an eye-opener, in
title: POSTING; Luxe Invades Rockaway Park

body: IF you could choose between the life you imagined for yourself a decade ago and the one you've actually lived since then, which would you prefer? Gitta Robinson and Richard Grisaru don't mind at all that their lives haven't turned out according to plan. Ten years ago, the couple, both architects, came up with a strategy: they would buy a house in
title: HABITATS/Clinton Hill; From the Beginning, It Felt Like Home

body: One of the great things about installation art is that it can be made of almost anything -- a snow shovel, empty space, even a few tons of dirt -- and it can be found almost anywhere. To find some late on Saturday night, it was necessary to meet a wary, tattooed man named Duke Riley in the parking lot of a lobster restaurant in Sheepshead Bay,
title: When Making Art Becomes a Night at the Beach

body: TO get to the semi-renovated Brooklyn loft where the Theater of a Two-Headed Calf holds its monthly gatherings, guests have to walk up two flights of dilapidated stairs. The elevator is broken. But that has not deterred the 100 or so artists, writers and musicians who have gathered on this spring evening to drink, talk, watch and maybe perform. The
title: THEATER; Shaw, Kabuki, Eva Peron: The Usual Mix

body: A FORMER executive with Goldman Sachs and J. P. Morgan Chase paid $5.8 million this month for two adjoining apartments at 1 Main Street in Dumbo, Brooklyn. The two units, with a combined 4,790 square feet, have views of the East River and Manhattan. The buyers were Mino Capossela, the former executive, and his wife, Maura McDonnell. The building, a
title: BIG DEAL; Dumbo Is Humble No More

body: A group of Brooklyn College graduate art students whose thesis exhibition was shut down last month have filed a federal suit against New York City, the Parks Department and the college, claiming that their free-speech rights were violated and that their work was damaged when it was removed. On May 4, a day after the exhibition opened, the Brooklyn
title: Arts, Briefly; Art Students File Suit

body: IT'S all gone: every diamond ring, every stack of bills and birth certificate. Today, the safe deposit boxes in the subterranean vault of what used to be the Williamsburgh Savings Bank lie empty in haphazard piles on the dusty floor. The massive vault doors, several feet thick, stand open. No calls will ever go out to Mrs. Helen Massone, whose
title: For Brooklyn's Beacon, The Luxe Life

''You really only do this if you're addicted; it's more like a
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DUMBO; The 'Orchid Man' Fights for His Friends

One, backed up against the Manhattan Bridge just outside the F train stop, is ramshackle blue plywood, covered with photocopies of building permits and signs for construction companies. title: Side By Side

body: As arson investigators continued examining evidence collected from the scene of a huge 10-alarm fire on May 2 at the Greenpoint Terminal Market, its owner, Joshua Guttman, spent yesterday in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn on an older and less headline-grabbing matter: the resolution of an 8-year-old lawsuit over an artist's missing equipment. Mr.
title: Controversial Landlord Meets His Match in Brooklyn Court

body: Delicate is not a word that would describe most brown rice. But Kalijira rice, an heirloom brown rice from India that has an extremely small grain, is exactly that. The rice cooks faster than most kinds of brown rice, in less than 30 minutes, and emerges as a fluffy pilaf with a light hazelnut flavor, making it a brown rice that is more Blahnik
title: FOOD STUFF; Brown Rice That's Shed Its Tie-Dye

body: The homely brick building had been a factory, and then a coffee processing plant and a place where street vendors parked their food carts. It became a warren of wide-open loft apartments. Later, it was the center of a lawsuit and the scene of a four-alarm fire, and it still stands, empty and black inside, with padlocks on thick chains looped
title: The Lofts, a Landlord and a Battle to Remember

body: A group of graduate art students whose thesis exhibition was shut down last week after a city official found it offensive have accepted an offer by their college to relocate the show to the Dumbo neighborhood in Brooklyn. On May 4, a day after the Brooklyn College exhibition opened, the Brooklyn parks commissioner, Julius Spiegel, ordered it closed
title: Students Relocate a Shuttered Art Show

title: Arts, Briefly; Brooklyn College Faculty Condemns Art Ouster

body: FASHION comes from all quarters. It is found at an indie-rock festival, a poetry reading or a knitting circle. The members of a particular scene may not think of themselves as trend-setters, but by pulling themselves together just so, they define a look. This was true at Brooklyn's first Fashion Weekend, May 5 to 7, when 19 primarily local
title: Pulled Together; Born in Brooklyn: Something to Strut About

On Thursday, a day after the exhibition opened, the Brooklyn parks commissioner,
title: Brooklyn Art Exhibition Comes Down Amid Protest

body: There have been at least four deliberately set fires at properties linked to Joshua Guttman, the owner of a warehouse complex on the Brooklyn waterfront that burned to the ground this week in what Fire Department officials have called suspicious circumstances, according to records collected by fire marshals. title: Arson Was Found at 4 of Warehouse Owner's Properties

The woman, dressed in white like a 19th-century washerwoman, put her fingers to her lips and, with a wooden clothespin, underlined the words stenciled on
title: Get It Off Your Chest and Onto a Window

title: SQUARE FEET: INTERVIEW -- WITH BARRY M. GOSIN; Trained in Manhattan, Graduating to the World

title: Art in Review; Lisa Ross

body: A GLASS-TOPPED dining table may be convenient, and steel may be contemporary, but a slab of wood is timeless. Wood slab tables retain a handmade look as well as the soul of a forest. They complement every décor from traditional to modern, and since many tables come in a variety of sizes, they can fit into most spaces. They also span a wide price
title: PERSONAL SHOPPER; Going With the Grain

body: Edible Brooklyn, a free quarterly, covers the food scene in its namesake borough. The first issue provides close-ups of Acme Smoked Fish in Greenpoint, Jacques Torres Chocolate in Dumbo and the seltzer delivery business, along with a tour of Sunset Park Chinatown with Ed Schoenfeld. Greenmarket locations are given, as well as a list of seasonal
title: FOOD STUFF; From Soup to Nuts, and in Between, in Brooklyn

title: FOOD STUFF; Choice Ingredients For Urban Gatherers

body: GENTLEMEN: just because you are bachelors living alone does not mean that you have bachelor pads. A studio with a duct-taped beanbag chair and a beer can sculpture is not a bachelor pad. You are also disqualified if guests have reason to fear setting foot in your bathroom or are forced to drink from plastic cups. A bachelor pad is a cultural icon.
title: The Bachelor Pad Still Lives

body: THE first time Pep Gay went to Brooklyn, he was scared. It was 1996, and he had arrived in New York a year earlier from Spain, where he had spent his youth helping cut meat at his parents' carnicería in Barcelona. In New York he had been so immersed in getting his career as a makeup artist off the ground that he had hadn't really noticed that
title: HABITATS/Dumbo; A Pioneer Knows When to Move On

author: Jeff Byles is the author of ''Rubble: Unearthing the History of Demolition.''
body: ON May 22, 1936, the photographer Berenice Abbott ambled along the Brooklyn waterfront, thrilling to river-wrapped vistas and old warehouses that glowered with imposing grandeur. Crossing the narrow streets on one of her celebrated sorties to shoot the surging metropolis for the federal Works Progress Administration, she turned her lens upon a
title: Amid the Facades, Furrowed Brows

body: Modern dance from Japan is much among us these days, ubiquitous and mysterious. title: For Whom Will the Foghorn Blow?

title: URBAN TACTICS; A Desire Named Streetcar

body: Matthew Kenney is on a meatless mission. If he has his way, we New Yorkers will amputate our lamb shanks and bid our poussin adieu. We'll live as one big, happy, herbivorous family, with veggie troughs on every block. They will be provided by Mr. Kenney, a titan of tofu, an emperor of roughage. Or so it seems from his frenzy of bright green
title: Diner's Journal
